text: When in fact where you really learn where the challenges are or the problems or the successes is by just being there with the people in the trenches on one of the things, whichever one seems hardest or most complicated. And so I try to do that as often as I can, and I found that I always learn a lot by going through that detailed exercise.
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Jeremy is explaining his leadership philosophy and approach to maintaining velocity at scale. He discusses the importance of leaders not just delegating from above but actually engaging directly with the detailed work. Jeremy emphasizes that rather than just floating above and directing teams from a distance, effective leaders must dive deep into the most challenging problems alongside their teams to truly understand what's happening and learn from the process.
text_ko: 사실 진짜로 어디에 도전 과제나 문제가 있고, 또 어디서 성공이 일어나는지는 가장 어렵거나 복잡해 보이는 일 하나에 대해 실무자들과 함께 현장에 직접 있어 봐야 알게 돼요. 그래서 저는 가능한 한 자주 그렇게 하려고 하고, 그 세부적인 과정을 겪어 보면 항상 많은 걸 배우게 되더라고요.
text_zh: 其实真正了解挑战在哪里、问题在哪里、成功在哪里，就得跟一线的人待在一起，特别是那些最难搞、最复杂的事情。所以我尽量多这样做，我发现每次深入了解这些细节，都能学到很多东西。
text_es: La realidad es que donde verdaderamente aprendes cuáles son los retos, los problemas o los éxitos es simplemente estando ahí con la gente que está en primera línea trabajando en los temas más difíciles o complicados. Entonces trato de hacer esto lo más seguido que puedo, y he descubierto que siempre aprendo muchísimo cuando me meto de lleno en esos detalles.

text: I think the biggest challenge was that in crypto there's just so much uncertainty in general, simple questions like, is Ethereum going to be a thing, are the subject of debate. And no one actually at the time had an answer to that question. Lots of really strong opinions and so you have to be able to have those debates because lots is going on, but then you have to be able to come out of those conversations with a clear kind of company point of view that you're all shooting toward.
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about the biggest challenges of keeping a team focused during Coinbase's period of explosive growth. Jeremy explains the unique difficulties of working in the crypto industry during its volatile early days. He describes how fundamental questions about the future of cryptocurrencies like Ethereum were completely uncertain, yet teams still needed to make decisive product decisions and maintain alignment despite this ambiguity.
text_ko: 제일 큰 난제는 크립토(crypto) 분야가 전반적으로 불확실성이 너무 컸다는 거였어요. 이더리움(Ethereum)이 과연 자리잡을지 같은 간단한 질문조차 논쟁거리였죠. 그때는 사실 아무도 그 질문에 대한 답을 갖고 있지 않았고요. 의견들이 워낙 강해서 그런 논쟁을 할 줄 알아야 했고, 일이 많이 벌어지니 그럴 수밖에 없었어요. 하지만 그런 대화들에서 결국 모두가 향할 수 있는 분명한 회사 입장을 정리해 내야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得最大的挑战就是，加密货币这个领域不确定性太强了，连"以太坊(Ethereum)到底能不能成"这种基本问题都还在争论。当时真的没人能给出确定答案。大家都有自己的强烈观点，所以你必须能够参与这些辩论，因为变化太快了，但同时你又得能从这些讨论中梳理出一个清晰的公司立场，让大家朝着同一个方向努力。
text_es: Creo que el mayor desafío fue que en las criptomonedas hay muchísima incertidumbre en general, preguntas súper básicas como si Ethereum va a funcionar o no, son tema de debate. Y nadie en ese momento tenía una respuesta clara a esa pregunta. Había un montón de opiniones muy fuertes, entonces tienes que poder tener esos debates porque están pasando muchas cosas, pero después tienes que lograr salir de esas conversaciones con una visión clara de la empresa hacia la que todos están apuntando.

text: I think there's kind of a universal truth that you want small teams with clear missions. Right? If there's 300 people trying to work on one thing, the just sheer communication challenges, Dunbar's number, all of those things come into play and it's really, really hard to act quickly. And so having smaller groups of people breaking down what is always a very, very large problem into sufficiently small bits that small groups can attack wholeheartedly and minimize horizontal communication, I think is the first thing.
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about maintaining velocity at scale, which is advice people frequently seek from Jeremy. Jeremy outlines his framework for keeping teams productive as companies grow. He explains that one of the universal principles is organizing work around small, focused teams rather than large groups, referencing concepts like Dunbar's number to explain why large groups struggle with coordination and decision-making speed.
text_ko: 작은 팀에 명확한 미션을 주는 게 보편적인 진리인 것 같아요. 예를 들어 한 가지 일에 300명이 달라붙으면 순수한 의사소통 문제, 던바 수(Dunbar's number) 같은 요소들이 다 작용해서 빠르게 움직이기가 정말 어렵거든요. 그래서 언제나 아주 큰 문제를 소규모 팀이 온전히 몰입해서 해결할 수 있을 만큼 충분히 작은 단위로 쪼개고, 수평적 소통(horizontal communication)을 최소화하는 게 첫 번째라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得有个普遍的道理，就是你得要小团队，目标还得明确。对吧？如果300个人都在搞同一件事，光是沟通就够你受的，什么邓巴数字(Dunbar's number)这些问题全都冒出来了，想要快速行动根本不可能。所以呢，让小团队把那些超级复杂的大问题拆解成小块，让每个小组都能全力以赴地去攻克，尽量减少横向沟通，我觉得这是最关键的。
text_es: Creo que hay como una verdad universal y es que necesitas equipos pequeños con misiones claras. ¿No? Si tienes 300 personas tratando de trabajar en una sola cosa, nada más los desafíos de comunicación, el número de Dunbar (Dunbar's number), todas esas cosas entran en juego y se vuelve súper, súper difícil actuar rápido. Entonces, tener grupos más pequeños de gente que dividan lo que siempre es un problema gigantesco en pedacitos lo suficientemente pequeños para que equipos chicos puedan atacarlos con todo y minimizar la comunicación horizontal, creo que eso es lo primero.

text: And in that set of optimizations, you are minimizing the deeper product thinking about what can fully differentiate our product based on not only existing kind of capabilities within our products and platform, but based on what it ought to do in the future. And so it sort of limits product creativity, but worse, it leads to building the wrong thing technically, right?
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about his philosophy on MVPs (minimum viable products), as he's heard Jeremy is not a big fan of them. Jeremy explains why he believes MVPs can be counterproductive, particularly for companies like Rippling. He argues that when you optimize purely for speed with an MVP approach, you sacrifice the deeper strategic thinking about product differentiation and future scalability, which can lead to fundamental technical architecture mistakes.
vocabulary_highlights: leads to building the wrong thing
text_ko: 그런 최적화 과정(optimizations)에만 매몰되면 제품을 진짜로 차별화할 수 있는 부분에 대한 깊은 고민을 줄여 버려요. 제품·플랫폼(platform) 내 기존 기능들(capabilities)만 기준으로 삼고 앞으로 제품이 어떻게 돼야 하는지까지 생각하지 않게 되거든요. 그래서 제품 창의성(product creativity)이 제한되고, 더 나쁜 건 기술적으로(technically) 잘못된 것을 만들게 된다는 거예요.
text_zh: 在这种优化思路下，你其实是在弱化更深层的产品思考——就是我们的产品到底应该怎么做才能真正有差异化，不光是基于现有的产品功能和平台能力，更要考虑未来应该往哪个方向发展。这样一来呢，不仅限制了产品的创新思维，更糟糕的是，在技术层面可能会做出完全错误的东西，对吧？
text_es: Y con ese enfoque de optimizaciones, terminas minimizando el pensamiento más profundo sobre el producto - o sea, qué es lo que realmente puede diferenciar nuestro producto, no solo basándose en las capacidades que ya tenemos en nuestros productos y plataforma, sino en lo que debería hacer a futuro. Entonces como que limita la creatividad del producto, pero peor aún, te lleva a construir la cosa equivocada técnicamente, ¿no?

text: The idea of a compound startup for us is that we're basically a lot of businesses that all work together. If you think about the products we offer, we have payroll, well, there's entire companies built just on payroll, insurance, and benefits, entire companies. That's our entire life cycle of a whole company.
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Lenny asks Jeremy to explain Rippling's concept of being a 'compound startup' and how this approach impacts their product development and team organization. Jeremy describes how Rippling operates multiple distinct business lines that could each be standalone companies - like payroll, benefits, insurance, and IT management - but they're all built on a unified platform. He's explaining the strategic vision behind building multiple interconnected products rather than focusing on just one vertical.
text_ko: '컴파운드 스타트업(compound startup)'이라는 개념은, 저희 입장에선 기본적으로 서로 함께 작동하는 여러 사업들이 모여 있는 형태예요. 우리가 제공하는 상품을 보면 급여(payroll), 보험(insurance), 복리후생(benefits) 같은 것들이 있고, 사실 급여만으로도 하나의 회사가 될 정도로 독립된 비즈니스가 있어요. 그런 것들이 모여서 한 회사의 전체 라이프사이클(life cycle)을 아우르는 셈이에요.
text_zh: 我们这种复合型初创公司(compound startup)的概念就是，我们其实是把很多业务都整合在一起了。你想想我们提供的产品，有工资发放、保险、福利这些，光是工资发放这一块，就有专门的公司在做，保险和福利也是，都有整个公司专门搞这个。我们这等于是覆盖了一个公司的整个生命周期。
text_es: Para nosotros, la idea de una startup compuesta es que somos básicamente un montón de negocios que trabajan todos juntos. Si te pones a pensar en los productos que ofrecemos, tenemos nóminas, bueno, hay empresas enteras que se dedican solo a nóminas, seguros y beneficios, empresas completas. Eso es todo nuestro ciclo de vida de una empresa entera.

text: I would say it's fundamental, speed of execution. I think in speed of decision-making. It's the thing that is probably the hardest to explain to people before they're here. It's hard to understand until you experience it. It's like let's not schedule a meeting for next week or tomorrow or later today. We're in the middle of a meeting, we need to make a decision.
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about unique aspects of Rippling's culture that he hasn't mentioned yet. Jeremy identifies their exceptionally fast pace of execution and decision-making as the most distinctive cultural element. He explains that this speed is so extreme that it's difficult for outsiders to comprehend - instead of scheduling meetings to make decisions, they make decisions immediately within ongoing conversations, even if it means pulling in additional people on the spot.
text_ko: 제일 근본적인 건 실행 속도(speed of execution)예요. 특히 의사결정 속도(speed of decision-making)이요. 여기 오기 전엔 사람들에게 설명하기가 아마 제일 힘들어요. 직접 겪어보기 전엔 잘 와닿지 않거든요. 예를 들면 '다음 주에 하자' '내일 하자' '오늘 늦게 하자'처럼 회의를 미루지 않아요. 회의 도중이라도 결정을 내려야 하면 바로 결정을 내리는 문화예요.
text_zh: 我觉得最根本的就是执行速度，还有决策速度。这个东西可能是最难跟外面的人解释清楚的，不亲身经历真的很难理解。就是那种，别什么下周开会、明天开会，甚至今天晚点开会，我们现在就在开会，现在就得把这事儿定下来。
text_es: Yo diría que es fundamental, la velocidad de ejecución. Me refiero a la velocidad para tomar decisiones. Es lo que probablemente más cuesta explicarle a la gente antes de que llegue aquí. Es difícil de entender hasta que no lo vives. Es como... no vamos a programar una reunión para la próxima semana o para mañana o para más tarde. Estamos en plena reunión, tenemos que decidir ya.

text: In product, you don't own little feature, you own your product and you're expected to be the world's foremost expert in it. And if you are, what that means is instead of having to come back to people three days later with an answer, just off the top of your head, you can be like, 'Yes, this is what I think I should do about that or give me 30 minutes, look something up and I can tell you what we need to do about that.'
speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
context: Jeremy is explaining how Rippling creates a culture of fast decision-making. He describes their expectation that product managers must become deep domain experts in their areas rather than just managing small features. This deep expertise enables them to make quick decisions without lengthy research periods. Jeremy is outlining how this preparation and knowledge depth directly enables their culture of rapid execution and immediate decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: off the top of your head
text_ko: 제품(product) 업무에서는 작은 기능(feature) 하나만 맡는 게 아니라 제품 전체를 책임져야 하고, 그 제품에 대해서는 세상에서 가장 잘 아는 사람이 돼야 한다고 기대받아요. 그리고 실제로 그렇게 된다면 사람들한테 답을 들고 3일 뒤에 다시 오지 않아도 돼요. 바로 머릿속에서 떠오르는 대로 "응, 이건 이렇게 해야 할 것 같아"라고 말할 수도 있고, "30분만 줘, 찾아보고 우리가 뭘 해야 할지 알려줄게"라고 바로 답할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 做产品的话，你不是只负责某个小功能，而是要对整个产品负责，而且得成为这个领域的绝对专家。如果你真的做到了，那就意味着别人问你问题的时候，你不用过三天才给答复，而是可以马上说："嗯，我觉得应该这么处理"，或者"给我半小时查一下资料，我就能告诉你该怎么办。"
text_es: En producto, no eres dueño de una funcionalidad específica, sino de todo tu producto y se espera que seas el mayor experto del mundo en él. Y si lo eres, eso significa que en lugar de tener que volver con la gente tres días después con una respuesta, así de inmediato, puedes decir: "Sí, esto es lo que creo que deberíamos hacer al respecto" o "dame 30 minutos para revisar algo y te digo qué tenemos que hacer con eso."
